questions.text: A 3-weeks-old baby presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting after every meal. Abdominal examination reveals prominent peristalsis in the epigastrium and an olive-sized mass is felt on deep palpation of the right upper abdomen. Which of the following drug exposures is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It is associated with exposure to azithromycin.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Trisomy 18
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Hyperplasia of the pyloric muscularis propria obstructs the gastric outflow tract.

It is three to five times more common in males. Generally presents between 3rd and 6th weeks of life as new-onset regurgitation, projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. Physical examination reveals a firm, ovoid, 1 to 2 cm abdominal mass. In some cases, abnormal left to right hyperperistalsis is seen.

Treatment is the surgical splitting of the muscularis (Ramstedt pyloromyotomy).

questions.text: Endoscopy of a patient with chronic upper gastrointestinal bleeding showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The endoscopy findings of the watermelon stomach are suggestive of gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE).

In GAVE, endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon. GAVE is responsible for 4% of non-variceal upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Dieulafoy lesion is a non-stress-related cause of GI bleeding. It is due to a submucosal artery that does not branch properly within the wall of the stomach. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes mellitus is on dialysis for chronic renal failure. Which of the following forms of gastritis is the patient at risk of development?
questions.solution:
Patients with renal failure develop acute gastritis as a consequence of uremia.

In uremia, gastric injury is due to inhibition of gastric bicarbonate transporters by ammonium ions.

Causes of acute gastritis:

  • Alcohol
  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Smoking
  • Ischemia/shock
  • Steroid use
  • Uremia
  • Chemical ingestion
  • Stress

Histologically, the presence of neutrophils above the basement membrane in direct contact with epithelial cells signifies acute gastritis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic gastritis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of chronic gastritis is infection with the bacillus Helicobacter pylori.

Causes of chronic gastritis:

  • Helicobacter pylori - 1st most common
  • Autoimmune gastritis - 2nd most common
  • Radiation injury
  • Chronic bile reflux
  • Mechanical injury (e.g., an indwelling nasogastric tube)
  • Systemic diseases such as Crohn disease, amyloidosis
  • Graft-versus-host disease

Options B and C: Acid hypersecretion and alcohol ingestion are the causes of acute gastritis.

Note: Autoimmune gastritis is the most common cause of diffuse atrophic gastritis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcers underwent an upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy was stained with a special stain as shown in the image. Identify the special stain used.
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the Helicobacter pylori bacilli.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin-Starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

The image given below is GI biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

The below image is a Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with nausea and upper abdominal pain. He experiences vague discomfort mostly in the afternoon and night, which is relieved by food. The urea breath test is positive. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a small ulcer with a clean base in the duodenum. From which of the following sites should the biopsy be taken to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of H. pylori gastritis. The preferred site for biopsy is the antrum as H. pylori are most often found in the antrum of the stomach.

H. pylori display tropism for gastric epithelia and are generally not found in the duodenal epithelium. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis may extend to involve the body and fundus, resulting in patchy mucosal atrophy.

The below image is a Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium of the antrum.

questions.text: In patients with autoimmune gastritis, what part of the stomach is least likely to get involved?
questions.solution:
Autoimmune gastritis typically spares the antrum.

Autoimmune gastritis causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa, within the body and fundus. It accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis. CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+/K+ ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis.

Characteristic features of autoimmune gastritis:

  • Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor
  • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
  • Hypergastrinemia
  • Endocrine cell hyperplasia leads to carcinoid tumors
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia)
  • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)

questions.text: What is the most common site of peptic ulcers?
questions.solution:
The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum.

Locations of peptic ulcers (in decreasing order of frequency):

  1. Duodenum (first part)
  2. Stomach (lesser curvature near the junction of body and antrum)
  3. Gastroesophageal junction in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or Barrett’s esophagus
  4. Margins of jejunostomy
  5. Stomach, duodenum, and/or jejunum in patients with Zollinger–Ellison syndrome
  6. Ileal Meckel’s diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa

The below image shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval, sharply punched-out defect, and clean mucosal margin

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with periodic abdominal pain. The pain is associated with meals and is relieved by antacids. Physical examination is unremarkable. Endoscopy shows a mucosal ulcer. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of peptic ulcers is bleeding.

An ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum causes bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery. Gastric ulcer on the lesser curvature of the stomach causes bleeding from the left gastric artery.

Other complications are perforation, obstruction, and malignant transformation.

Note: The most common cause of death in peptic ulcers is perforation followed by bleeding. Perforation accounts for two-thirds of ulcer deaths.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with severe burns is most likely at risk of developing which of the following ulcers?
questions.solution:
Curling's ulcers are associated with severe burns or trauma.

Curling's ulcers occur in the proximal duodenum. Systemic hypotension or reduced blood flow caused by stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction results in gastric mucosal injury.

Note: Cushing's ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation.

questions.text: The upper gastrointestinal endoscopy of a patient is shown below. Excessive secretion of which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopy image showing irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae in the body is suggestive of Ménétrier disease. It is due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor α (TGF-α).

Menetrier disease is one of the causes of hypertrophic gastropathy. It is associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults.

Below histological image shows hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance.

questions.text: Fundic gland polyps are associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Fundic gland polyps are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Fundic gland polyps may also occur sporadically or with proton pump inhibitor use. They occur in the gastric body and fundus. 

They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain. 

Dysplasia and neoplasia may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma.

The below histological image of fundic gland polyp shows cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastric adenoma?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastric adenoma is the antrum.

Gastric adenomas are premalignant neoplastic lesions. Patients are usually between 50 and 60 years of age. Males are affected three times more often than females. 

The majority of adenomas are composed of intestinal-type columnar epithelium that exhibits varying degrees of dysplasia.

questions.text: All are predisposing factors for the development of gastric adenoma except:
questions.solution:
Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is not a predisposing factor for the development of gastric adenoma. It may predispose to carcinoid tumors.

Risk factors for gastric adenoma:

  • Chronic gastritis with atrophy
  • Intestinal metaplasia
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis

The risk of adenocarcinoma in gastric adenomas is particularly increased in lesions greater than 2 cm in diameter. Overall, carcinoma may be present in up to 30% of gastric adenomas.

questions.text: Which germline loss-of-function mutation is strongly associated with patients diagnosed with familial gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Familial gastric cancer (diffuse type) is strongly associated with germline loss-of-function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CDH1. It encodes the cell adhesion protein, E-cadherin.

Half of the sporadic diffuse gastric cancer cases occur due to loss-of-function mutations in CDH1. In the remaining cases, E-cadherin expression is decreased, due to hypermethylation and silencing of the CDH1promoter. Thus, the loss of E-cadherin is a key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer.

Sporadic intestinal-type gastric cancers are strongly associated with increased signaling via the Wnt pathway (loss-of-function mutation of APC/gain-of-function mutation of β-catenin).

Mutation of TP53 is also found in the majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both types.

questions.text: Linitis plastica is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Linitis plastica or leather bottle stomach or Brintons's disease is seen in diffuse gastric cancer.

Diffuse gastric cancer is an infiltrative tumor and often evokes a desmoplastic reaction that stiffens the gastric wall. When there are large areas of infiltration, diffuse rugal flattening and a rigid, thickened wall may impart a leather bottle appearance as shown below.

questions.text: All are true about diffuse gastric cancer except:
questions.solution:
The diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma does not form bulky tumors. It grows in a diffuse infiltrating pattern that stiffens the gastric wall (linitis plastica). In contrast, the intestinal type tends to form bulky masses.

Loss of E-cadherin is the key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer, resulting in discohesive cells. These single cells have large, intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles that push the nucleus to the periphery, creating a signet-ring cell morphology. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types.

The below H&E-stained smear shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Note: Loss of E cadherin is also seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with severe unintentional weight loss was found to have gastric cancer. This cancer is least likely to metastasize to which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Right axillary lymph nodes are least likely to be involved in gastric cancer metastasis.

Sites most commonly involved in gastric cancer metastasis include the following:

  • Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node (Virchow node)
  • Periumbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph nodule)
  • Left axillary lymph node (Irish node)
  • Ovary (Krukenberg tumor)
  • Pouch of Douglas (Blumer shelf)

questions.text: What is the most common translocation seen in patients with gastric MALToma?
questions.solution:
The most common translocation in gastric MALToma is t(11;18)(q21;q21).

Three translocations are associated with gastric MALToma:

  1. t(11;18)(q21;q21) - Most common
  2. t(1;14)(p22;q32)
  3. t(14;18)(q32;q21)

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with long-standing chronic gastritis undergoes an endoscopic biopsy. The biopsy showed dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands. The cells of this tumor are likely to express all of the following markers except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of gastric MALToma. The tumor cells express the B-cell markers CD19 and CD20. They do not express CD5 or CD10.

They are positive for CD43 in about 25% of cases, a T-cell marker that can be diagnostically helpful.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be secreted by gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors can secrete all of the above-mentioned secretory products except noradrenaline.

Carcinoid products at different sites:

  • Stomach - Histamine, somatostatin, serotonin
  • Duodenum - Gastrin, somatostatin, cholecystokinin
  • Jejunum and ileum - Serotonin, substance P, polypeptide YY
  • Colon - Serotonin, polypeptide YY.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: At which site are the most aggressive carcinoid tumors of the gastrointestinal system seen?
questions.solution:
The most aggressive carcinoid tumors of the GIT are seen in the jejunum and ileum.

Carcinoid tumors occur throughout the GI tract. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum.

Ileal carcinoid with metastasis to the liver cause carcinoid syndrome because the vasoactive substances escape the filtering actions of the liver. This is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

The behavior of the carcinoid tumors differs according to their location:

  • Foregut carcinoid tumor
    • Stomach; duodenum, proximal to the ligament of Treitz; and esophagus
    • Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
    • Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors
    • Variable behavior
    • Rarely metastasize and are generally cured by resection
    • Gastric carcinoid tumors without predisposing factors are often more aggressive
  • Midgut carcinoid tumor
    • Arise in the jejunum and ileum
    • Often multiple
    • Tend to be aggressive
  • Hindgut carcinoid
    • Arise in the appendix and colorectum
    • Appendiceal tumors are usually < 2 cm in diameter and are almost always benign
    • Metastasis of rectal carcinoid tumors is uncommon

Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. On examination, her face appears flushed and her pulse is 120/min. Increased levels of 5-HIAA are observed in a 24-hour urinary sample. Which of the following is not a prognostic factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of carcinoid tumors. The most important prognostic factors include the degree of histological differentiation, mitotic rate, and Ki-67 proliferative index. 

The diagnosis of carcinoid tumor is made by increased levels of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors or if metastases are present.

Note: The most important prognostic factor for esophageal carcinoma and stomach carcinoma is the depth of invasion.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man underwent resection of a localized gastrointestinal tumor arising from the stomach. Histopathological examination showed a gain-of-function mutation in the KIT gene and positivity for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). It arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal, or pacemaker cells, of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

It is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. The peak age of incidence is 60 years.

In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Inherited/germline GIST is seen in Carney–Stratakis syndrome. It is due to loss-of-function mutation of SDH which has increased risk for GIST and paraganglioma.

GIST at a younger age is associated with the following:

  •  Carney triad:
    • Gastric GIST
    • Paraganglioma
    • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1

Grossly, it usually forms a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass covered by ulcerated or intact mucosa.

Histologically, the tumor is composed of spindle cells (most common), epithelioid cells, or mixed cell types.

The below image shows microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells

Complete surgical resection is the primary treatment for localized gastric GIST.

Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat CML, can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA.

The FDA recently approved Avapritinib, for the treatment of adults with unresectable or metastatic GIST harboring a platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (PDGFR-A) exon 18 mutation, including PDGFRA D842V mutations.

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: What is the most specific marker for a gastrointestinal stromal tumor?
questions.solution:
The most specific marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is DOG-1.

KIT (CD117) is the best diagnostic marker (most sensitive marker) of GIST. However, 5–10% of GIST lack KIT expression. DOG-1 is expressed in all GIST, including CD117-negative cases. Hence, DOG-1 marker is most specific for GIST.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

Option A: Carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor.

Option B: Lymphoma is a lymphoid tumor.

Option C: GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen.

questions.text: The absence of the structure marked as A will present with all except:
questions.solution:
The eosinophilic appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells, the absence of which is not associated with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome. The cells marked as B are Chief cells. 

Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, which leads to parital cell hyperplasia. Gastrinomas are almost always found in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature found in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

 

Other options:

Option A and C: Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF) that is released from the parietal cells, which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

Option B: Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells. They are referred to as well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors. The peak incidence of carcinoid tumors is in the 6th decade. These tumors occur throughout the GI tract, most commonly in the appendix, ileum, and rectum, in decreasing order of frequency.

Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. Ileal carcinoid may cause carcinoid syndrome which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.
